targets.description: By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $2.15 a day.
key_indicators: 1.1.1: Proportion of population below the international poverty line, by sex, age, employment status and geographical location (urban/rural)

targets.description: By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.
key_indicators: 1.2.1: Proportion of population living below the national poverty line, by sex and age
1.2.2: Proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions

targets.description: Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable by 2030.
key_indicators: 1.3.1: Proportion of population covered by social protection floors/systems, by sex, distinguishing children, unemployed persons, older persons, persons with disabilities, pregnant women, newborns, work-injury victims and the poor and the vulnerable

targets.description: By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.
key_indicators: 1.4.1: Proportion of population living in households with access to basic services
1.4.2: Proportion of total adult population with secure tenure rights to land, with legally recognized documentation and who perceive their rights to land as secure, by sex and by type of tenure

targets.description: By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.
key_indicators: 1.5.1: Number of deaths, missing persons and directly affected persons attributed to disasters per 100,000 population
1.5.2: Direct economic loss attributed to disasters in relation to global gross domestic product (GDP)
1.5.3: Number of countries with national and local disaster risk reduction strategies

targets.description: Ensure significant mobilization of resources from a variety of sources, including through enhanced development cooperation, in order to provide adequate and predictable means for developing countries, in particular least developed countries, to end poverty in all its dimensions.
key_indicators: 1.a.1: Proportion of domestically generated resources allocated by the government directly to poverty reduction programmes
1.a.2: Proportion of total government spending on essential services (education, health and social protection)

targets.description: Create sound policy frameworks at the national, regional and international levels, based on pro-poor and gender-sensitive development strategies, to support accelerated investment in poverty eradication actions.
key_indicators: 1.b.1: Proportion of government recurrent and capital spending to sectors that disproportionately benefit women, the poor and vulnerable groups

progress.global_progress_percentage: Approximately 75% of countries are off track
key_statistics: In 2022, an estimated 8.4% of the world population lived in extreme poverty, up from 8.3% in 2019 due to the COVID-19 pandemic and global crises.
Sub-Saharan Africa accounts for about 60% of the world’s extreme poor.
Children are disproportionately affected: more than 1 in 5 children live in extreme poverty globally.
Social protection coverage for vulnerable groups remains low, with only 47% of the global population covered by at least one social protection benefit.

challenges.challenge: Economic shocks, conflict, and climate change are reversing decades of progress in poverty reduction.
challenges.impact: Millions have fallen back into extreme poverty, especially in fragile and conflict-affected regions.

challenges.challenge: Limited access to social protection systems for the most vulnerable populations.
challenges.impact: Increased vulnerability to economic downturns, disasters, and health crises.

challenges.challenge: Rising food and energy prices due to global crises.
challenges.impact: Reduced purchasing power and increased poverty rates among low-income households.

success_stories.initiative: Targeted poverty alleviation programs including rural infrastructure investment, social protection expansion, and microfinance.
success_stories.impact: Lifted over 800 million people out of extreme poverty between 1990 and 2020.

success_stories.initiative: Bolsa Família conditional cash transfer program providing financial aid to low-income families contingent on school attendance and health check-ups.
success_stories.impact: Reduced extreme poverty by more than 50% and improved health and education outcomes.

success_stories.initiative: Productive Safety Net Programme (PSNP) offering cash or food transfers to food-insecure households in exchange for participation in public works.
success_stories.impact: Helped millions avoid hunger and build resilience to shocks.

priority_actions: Expand and strengthen social protection systems, especially for the most vulnerable populations.
Promote inclusive economic growth and job creation, particularly in rural and marginalized areas.
Increase investment in education, health, and basic services to break the cycle of poverty.
Enhance resilience to shocks, including climate-related disasters and economic crises.
Foster gender equality and empower women and girls as key agents of poverty reduction.
Mobilize additional resources and strengthen international cooperation for poverty eradication.

interconnections.relationship: Poverty and hunger are closely linked; eradicating poverty helps reduce food insecurity and malnutrition.
Poverty limits access to healthcare, increasing vulnerability to disease and reducing life expectancy.
Education is a key pathway out of poverty, enabling better employment and income opportunities.
Women and girls are disproportionately affected by poverty; gender equality accelerates poverty reduction.

interconnections.related_sdg: SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth
interconnections.relationship: Inclusive economic growth and decent work opportunities are essential for sustainable poverty reduction.

targets.description: By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
key_indicators: 2.1.1 Prevalence of undernourishment
2.1.2 Prevalence of moderate or severe food insecurity in the population

targets.description: By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.
key_indicators: 2.2.1 Prevalence of stunting among children under 5 years of age
2.2.2 Prevalence of malnutrition (weight for height, height for age, weight for age)

targets.description: By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, Indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.
key_indicators: 2.3.1 Volume of production per labour unit by classes of farming/pastoral/forestry enterprise size
2.3.2 Average income of small-scale food producers

targets.description: By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.
key_indicators: 2.4.1 Proportion of agricultural area under productive and sustainable agriculture

targets.description: By 2020, maintain the genetic diversity of seeds, cultivated plants and farmed and domesticated animals and their related wild species, including through soundly managed and diversified seed and plant banks at the national, regional and international levels, and promote access to and fair and equitable sharing of benefits arising from the utilization of genetic resources and associated traditional knowledge.
key_indicators: 2.5.1 Number of plant and animal genetic resources for food and agriculture secured in either medium or long-term conservation facilities
2.5.2 Proportion of local breeds classified as being at risk of extinction

targets.description: Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries.
key_indicators: 2.a.1 The agriculture orientation index for government expenditures
2.a.2 Total official flows (official development assistance plus other official flows) to the agriculture sector

targets.description: Correct and prevent trade restrictions and distortions in world agricultural markets, including through the parallel elimination of all forms of agricultural export subsidies and all export measures with equivalent effect, in accordance with the mandate of the Doha Development Round.
key_indicators: 2.b.1 Agricultural export subsidies

targets.description: Adopt measures to ensure the proper functioning of food commodity markets and their derivatives and facilitate timely access to market information, including on food reserves, in order to help limit extreme food price volatility.
key_indicators: 2.c.1 Indicator of food price anomalies

key_statistics: In 2022, up to 783 million people faced hunger globally.
Nearly 2.4 billion people were moderately or severely food insecure in 2022.
148 million children under 5 were stunted in 2022.
Global hunger has increased since 2015, reversing previous progress.
The COVID-19 pandemic, conflict, and climate change have exacerbated food insecurity.

challenges.challenge: Armed conflict and political instability
challenges.impact: Disrupts food production, supply chains, and access to food, leading to acute food insecurity and famine conditions.

challenges.challenge: Climate change and extreme weather events
challenges.impact: Reduces agricultural productivity, causes crop failures, and increases food price volatility.

challenges.challenge: Economic downturns and rising food prices
challenges.impact: Limits affordability and access to nutritious food, especially for vulnerable populations.

challenges.challenge: Persistent inequalities in access to land, resources, and markets
challenges.impact: Small-scale producers, women, and marginalized groups face barriers to increasing productivity and income.

success_stories.initiative: Zero Hunger Program (Fome Zero) combining cash transfers, school feeding, and support for family farming.
success_stories.impact: Contributed to a 75% reduction in child malnutrition and a 50% reduction in hunger between 2003 and 2014.

success_stories.initiative: Community-based nutrition programs and investments in agricultural productivity.
success_stories.impact: Stunting among children under 5 reduced from 51% in 2000 to 28% in 2022.

success_stories.initiative: Productive Safety Net Programme providing food and cash transfers to vulnerable households.
success_stories.impact: Improved food security for over 8 million people and reduced poverty rates.

priority_actions: Scale up investments in sustainable and climate-resilient agriculture.
Expand social protection and nutrition programs for vulnerable groups.
Strengthen food systems to withstand shocks from conflict, climate, and economic crises.
Promote equitable access to land, resources, and markets for small-scale producers.
Reduce food loss and waste across the supply chain.
Enhance international cooperation and financing for food security.

interconnections.relationship: Ending hunger is closely linked to poverty reduction, as poverty is a primary driver of food insecurity.
Adequate nutrition is essential for health, reducing child mortality and improving maternal health.
Climate change impacts agricultural productivity and food security, requiring integrated solutions.
Empowering women in agriculture increases productivity and improves food security outcomes.

targets.description: By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
key_indicators: Maternal mortality ratio
Proportion of births attended by skilled health personnel

targets.description: By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age.
key_indicators: Under-5 mortality rate
Neonatal mortality rate

targets.description: By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
key_indicators: Number of new HIV infections per 1,000 uninfected population
Tuberculosis incidence per 100,000 population
Malaria incidence per 1,000 population

targets.description: By 2030, reduce by one third premature mortality from non-communicable diseases through prevention and treatment and promote mental health and well-being.
key_indicators: Mortality rate attributed to cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes or chronic respiratory disease
Suicide mortality rate

targets.description: Strengthen the prevention and treatment of substance abuse, including narcotic drug abuse and harmful use of alcohol.
key_indicators: Coverage of treatment interventions for substance use disorders
Alcohol per capita consumption

targets.description: By 2030, halve the number of global deaths and injuries from road traffic accidents.
key_indicators: Death rate due to road traffic injuries

targets.description: By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services.
key_indicators: Proportion of women of reproductive age who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods
Adolescent birth rate

targets.description: Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.
key_indicators: Coverage of essential health services
Proportion of population with large household health expenditures as a share of total household expenditure

targets.description: By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.
key_indicators: Mortality rate attributed to household and ambient air pollution
Mortality rate attributed to unsafe water, unsafe sanitation and lack of hygiene

targets.description: Strengthen the implementation of the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control in all countries, as appropriate.
key_indicators: Age-standardized prevalence of current tobacco use among persons aged 15 years and older

targets.description: Support the research and development of vaccines and medicines for the communicable and non-communicable diseases that primarily affect developing countries.
key_indicators: Proportion of population with access to affordable medicines and vaccines
Total net official development assistance to medical research and basic health sectors

targets.description: Substantially increase health financing and recruitment, development, training and retention of the health workforce in developing countries.
key_indicators: Health worker density and distribution

targets.description: Strengthen the capacity of all countries for early warning, risk reduction and management of national and global health risks.
key_indicators: International Health Regulations (IHR) capacity and health emergency preparedness

key_statistics: Global maternal mortality ratio was 223 per 100,000 live births in 2020, far from the 2030 target.
In 2021, 5 million children under age 5 died, mostly from preventable causes.
HIV, tuberculosis, and malaria remain leading causes of death in low-income countries.
COVID-19 pandemic caused severe disruptions to essential health services in over 90% of countries.
Non-communicable diseases account for 74% of all deaths globally.

challenges.challenge: Insufficient health system capacity and workforce shortages.
challenges.impact: Limits access to essential health services, especially in rural and low-income areas.

challenges.challenge: High burden of communicable and non-communicable diseases.
challenges.impact: Strains health systems and increases premature mortality.

challenges.challenge: Inequitable access to vaccines and medicines.
challenges.impact: Exacerbates health disparities and slows progress towards universal health coverage.

challenges.challenge: Environmental pollution and unsafe water, sanitation, and hygiene.
challenges.impact: Leads to millions of preventable deaths annually, especially among children.

success_stories.initiative: Nationwide community health worker program to deliver essential health services and maternal care.
success_stories.impact: Under-5 mortality rate reduced by more than 60% between 2000 and 2020.

success_stories.initiative: Universal Health Coverage Scheme providing affordable access to health services.
success_stories.impact: Over 99% of the population covered by health insurance; significant reductions in out-of-pocket health expenditures.

success_stories.initiative: Intensified Mission Indradhanush for expanded immunization coverage.
success_stories.impact: Full immunization coverage increased from 62% in 2015 to 76% in 2021.

priority_actions: Strengthen primary health care systems and health workforce capacity.
Expand equitable access to vaccines, medicines, and essential health services.
Increase investment in health infrastructure and financing, especially in low-income countries.
Address non-communicable diseases through prevention, early detection, and treatment.
Improve data collection, monitoring, and health emergency preparedness.

interconnections.relationship: Poverty increases vulnerability to poor health outcomes and limits access to health services.
Malnutrition undermines health, especially for mothers and children.
Health education promotes healthy behaviors and improves health outcomes.
Access to clean water and sanitation reduces disease transmission and improves health.
Climate change impacts health through increased disease burden and health emergencies.

targets.description: By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
key_indicators: 4.1.1: Proportion of children and young people achieving at least a minimum proficiency level in reading and mathematics

targets.description: By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.
key_indicators: 4.2.1: Proportion of children under 5 years of age who are developmentally on track
4.2.2: Participation rate in organized learning (one year before the official primary entry age)

targets.description: By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.
key_indicators: 4.3.1: Participation rate of youth and adults in formal and non-formal education and training

targets.description: By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
key_indicators: 4.4.1: Proportion of youth and adults with information and communications technology (ICT) skills

targets.description: By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.
key_indicators: 4.5.1: Parity indices (female/male, rural/urban, bottom/top wealth quintile and others)

targets.description: By 2030, ensure that all youth and a substantial proportion of adults, both men and women, achieve literacy and numeracy.
key_indicators: 4.6.1: Proportion of population in a given age group achieving at least a fixed level of proficiency in functional literacy and numeracy

targets.description: By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and non-violence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture’s contribution to sustainable development.
key_indicators: 4.7.1: Extent to which (i) global citizenship education and (ii) education for sustainable development are mainstreamed

targets.description: Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.
key_indicators: 4.a.1: Proportion of schools with access to basic services (electricity, internet, computers, adapted infrastructure, water, sanitation, handwashing facilities)

targets.description: By 2020, substantially expand globally the number of scholarships available to developing countries, in particular least developed countries, small island developing States and African countries, for enrolment in higher education, including vocational training and information and communications technology, technical, engineering and scientific programmes.
key_indicators: 4.b.1: Volume of official development assistance flows for scholarships

targets.description: By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing States.
key_indicators: 4.c.1: Proportion of teachers with the minimum required qualifications

key_statistics: 244 million children and youth are out of school globally (2022, UNESCO)
Only 58% of children and adolescents worldwide achieve minimum proficiency in reading
COVID-19 caused the largest disruption of education in history, affecting over 1.6 billion learners at its peak
Girls are still more likely than boys to never set foot in a classroom, especially in Sub-Saharan Africa

challenges.challenge: Learning poverty and low proficiency in foundational skills
challenges.impact: Millions of children are in school but not learning basic reading and math, limiting future opportunities and perpetuating cycles of poverty.

challenges.challenge: Gender disparities and barriers for vulnerable groups
challenges.impact: Girls, children with disabilities, and those in conflict zones face significant barriers to accessing quality education, leading to exclusion and inequality.

challenges.challenge: Insufficient funding and infrastructure
challenges.impact: Lack of resources leads to overcrowded classrooms, underqualified teachers, and inadequate learning materials, undermining education quality.

success_stories.initiative: Comprehensive education reforms focusing on curriculum modernization, teacher training, and investment in school infrastructure.
success_stories.impact: Vietnam consistently outperforms many higher-income countries in international assessments such as PISA, with over 80% of students achieving minimum proficiency in reading and math.

success_stories.initiative: Implementation of a nationwide school feeding program and digital learning platforms to boost enrolment and retention.
success_stories.impact: Primary school enrolment rates exceeded 98%, and dropout rates decreased significantly.

success_stories.initiative: Expansion of stipend programs for girls and investments in rural schools.
success_stories.impact: Gender parity achieved in primary and secondary education enrolment.

priority_actions: Increase investment in education infrastructure and teacher training, especially in least developed countries.
Expand access to early childhood education and support for vulnerable groups.
Accelerate digital learning solutions to bridge the digital divide.
Strengthen policies to eliminate gender disparities and support inclusive education.
Enhance data collection and monitoring to inform evidence-based policy making.

interconnections.relationship: Quality education breaks the cycle of poverty by improving employment prospects and income.
Education empowers girls and women, reducing gender disparities and promoting equality.

interconnections.related_sdg: SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth
interconnections.relationship: Education equips individuals with skills for employment, entrepreneurship, and economic productivity.
Inclusive education reduces inequalities within and among countries.

interconnections.related_sdg: SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions
interconnections.relationship: Education fosters peaceful, just societies by promoting tolerance, citizenship, and human rights.

targets.description: End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
key_indicators: 5.1.1: Whether or not legal frameworks are in place to promote, enforce and monitor equality and non‑discrimination on the basis of sex

targets.description: Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
key_indicators: 5.2.1: Proportion of ever-partnered women and girls aged 15 years and older subjected to physical, sexual or psychological violence by a current or former intimate partner in the previous 12 months
5.2.2: Proportion of women and girls aged 15 years and older subjected to sexual violence by persons other than an intimate partner in the previous 12 months

targets.description: Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.
key_indicators: 5.3.1: Proportion of women aged 20–24 years who were married or in a union before age 15 and before age 18
5.3.2: Proportion of girls and women aged 15–49 years who have undergone female genital mutilation/cutting

targets.description: Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family.
key_indicators: 5.4.1: Proportion of time spent on unpaid domestic and care work, by sex, age and location

targets.description: Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
key_indicators: 5.5.1: Proportion of seats held by women in national parliaments and local governments
5.5.2: Proportion of women in managerial positions

targets.description: Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights.
key_indicators: 5.6.1: Proportion of women aged 15–49 years who make their own informed decisions regarding sexual relations, contraceptive use and reproductive health care
5.6.2: Number of countries with laws and regulations that guarantee full and equal access to women and men aged 15 years and older to sexual and reproductive health care, information and education

targets.description: Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources.
key_indicators: 5.a.1: Proportion of total agricultural population with ownership or secure rights over agricultural land, by sex
5.a.2: Proportion of countries where the legal framework guarantees women’s equal rights to land ownership and/or control

targets.description: Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
key_indicators: 5.b.1: Proportion of individuals who own a mobile telephone, by sex

targets.description: Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
key_indicators: 5.c.1: Proportion of countries with systems to track and make public allocations for gender equality and women’s empowerment

progress.global_progress_percentage: Approximately 65% of countries have legal frameworks to promote gender equality, but progress is slow.
key_statistics: Globally, 1 in 3 women have experienced physical or sexual violence.
129 million girls are out of school worldwide (2023).
Only 26.5% of seats in national parliaments are held by women (2023).
650 million women alive today were married before age 18.
Women spend three times as much time as men on unpaid care and domestic work.

challenges.challenge: Persistent gender-based violence, including domestic violence and sexual exploitation.
challenges.impact: Undermines women's physical and mental health, reduces participation in education and the workforce, and perpetuates cycles of poverty.

challenges.challenge: Limited access to education and economic opportunities for women and girls.
challenges.impact: Restricts women's ability to participate in decision-making, limits economic growth, and increases vulnerability to poverty.

challenges.challenge: Prevalence of harmful practices such as child marriage and female genital mutilation.
challenges.impact: Violates human rights, causes lifelong health complications, and limits educational and economic opportunities.

challenges.challenge: Underrepresentation of women in leadership and decision-making roles.
challenges.impact: Leads to policies that do not fully address women's needs and perpetuates gender inequality.

success_stories.initiative: Implementation of gender quotas in parliament and local government, ensuring at least 30% representation for women.
success_stories.impact: Women now hold 61% of seats in Rwanda's lower house of parliament, the highest in the world, leading to more inclusive legislation.

success_stories.initiative: Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao (Save the Girl Child, Educate the Girl Child) campaign to address declining child sex ratio and promote girls' education.
success_stories.impact: Improved child sex ratio in targeted districts and increased girls' enrollment in schools.

success_stories.initiative: Legal reforms to strengthen women's rights, including laws against domestic violence and equal inheritance rights.
success_stories.impact: Increased legal protection for women and higher reporting rates of gender-based violence.

priority_actions: Strengthen and enforce laws and policies to eliminate gender-based violence.
Increase investment in girls' education and skills development.
Promote women's economic empowerment and equal access to resources.
Expand access to sexual and reproductive health services.
Support women's leadership and participation in decision-making at all levels.
Address unpaid care and domestic work through social protection and infrastructure.
Combat harmful practices such as child marriage and female genital mutilation.

interconnections.relationship: Gender equality is essential to reducing poverty, as empowering women leads to higher household incomes and improved well-being.
Gender equality improves health outcomes by increasing access to health services and reducing gender-based violence.
Educating girls leads to greater gender equality and improved social and economic outcomes.

interconnections.related_sdg: SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth
interconnections.relationship: Women's participation in the workforce drives economic growth and productivity.
Achieving gender equality helps reduce social and economic inequalities within and among countries.

targets.description: By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.
key_indicators: 6.1.1: Proportion of population using safely managed drinking water services

targets.description: By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.
key_indicators: 6.2.1: Proportion of population using safely managed sanitation services, including a hand-washing facility with soap and water

targets.description: By 2030, improve water quality by reducing pollution, eliminating dumping and minimizing release of hazardous chemicals and materials, halving the proportion of untreated wastewater and substantially increasing recycling and safe reuse globally.
key_indicators: 6.3.1: Proportion of domestic and industrial wastewater flows safely treated
6.3.2: Proportion of bodies of water with good ambient water quality

targets.description: By 2030, substantially increase water-use efficiency across all sectors and ensure sustainable withdrawals and supply of freshwater to address water scarcity and substantially reduce the number of people suffering from water scarcity.
key_indicators: 6.4.1: Change in water-use efficiency over time
6.4.2: Level of water stress: freshwater withdrawal as a proportion of available freshwater resources

targets.description: By 2030, implement integrated water resources management at all levels, including through transboundary cooperation as appropriate.
key_indicators: 6.5.1: Degree of integrated water resources management implementation
6.5.2: Proportion of transboundary basin area with an operational arrangement for water cooperation

targets.description: By 2020, protect and restore water-related ecosystems, including mountains, forests, wetlands, rivers, aquifers and lakes.
key_indicators: 6.6.1: Change in the extent of water-related ecosystems over time

targets.description: By 2030, expand international cooperation and capacity-building support to developing countries in water- and sanitation-related activities and programmes, including water harvesting, desalination, water efficiency, wastewater treatment, recycling and reuse technologies.
key_indicators: 6.a.1: Amount of water- and sanitation-related official development assistance that is part of a government-coordinated spending plan

targets.description: Support and strengthen the participation of local communities in improving water and sanitation management.
key_indicators: 6.b.1: Proportion of local administrative units with established and operational policies and procedures for participation of local communities in water and sanitation management

key_statistics: 2.2 billion people lack safely managed drinking water services (2022)
3.5 billion people lack safely managed sanitation services (2022)
494 million people practice open defecation (2022)
Only 58% of wastewater is safely treated globally (2022)
Water stress affects over 2 billion people worldwide

challenges.challenge: Insufficient infrastructure and investment in water and sanitation systems
challenges.impact: Limits access to safe water and sanitation, particularly in rural and low-income urban areas, increasing health risks and perpetuating poverty

challenges.challenge: Water scarcity and over-extraction of freshwater resources
challenges.impact: Threatens water security for agriculture, industry, and households, leading to conflicts and migration

challenges.challenge: Water pollution from domestic, industrial, and agricultural sources
challenges.impact: Degrades water quality, harms ecosystems, and increases the cost of water treatment

success_stories.initiative: Nationwide installation of community-based water filtration systems and promotion of household sanitation facilities through the Community-Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) approach.
success_stories.impact: Open defecation reduced from 34% in 1990 to less than 1% in 2022; significant improvements in child health and reduction in waterborne diseases.

success_stories.initiative: National Water Plan focusing on integrated water resources management, investment in desalination plants, and expansion of rural water supply networks.
success_stories.impact: Access to improved drinking water increased to over 90% of the population; enhanced resilience to drought and water scarcity.

success_stories.initiative: Implementation of the 'Four National Taps' strategy, including NEWater (recycled water), desalination, imported water, and local catchment, ensuring water security.
success_stories.impact: 100% of the population has access to safe drinking water and sanitation; recognized as a global leader in water management.

priority_actions: Increase investment in water and sanitation infrastructure, especially in underserved regions
Strengthen governance and capacity for integrated water resources management
Promote water-use efficiency and conservation in agriculture, industry, and households
Expand wastewater treatment and safe reuse technologies
Enhance data collection and monitoring for informed decision-making
Support community-led initiatives and gender-sensitive approaches
Foster international cooperation and knowledge sharing

interconnections.relationship: Access to clean water and sanitation is essential for good health and well-being, reducing waterborne diseases and child mortality.
Water availability and quality are critical for sustainable agriculture and food security.
Climate change impacts water availability and quality, increasing the frequency and severity of droughts and floods.
Sustainable cities require resilient water and sanitation infrastructure to support growing populations.
Reducing land-based water pollution helps protect marine ecosystems and biodiversity.

targets.description: By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.
key_indicators: 7.1.1 Proportion of population with access to electricity
7.1.2 Proportion of population with primary reliance on clean fuels and technology

targets.description: By 2030, increase substantially the share of renewable energy in the global energy mix.
key_indicators: 7.2.1 Renewable energy share in the total final energy consumption

targets.description: By 2030, double the global rate of improvement in energy efficiency.
key_indicators: 7.3.1 Energy intensity measured in terms of primary energy and GDP

targets.description: By 2030, enhance international cooperation to facilitate access to clean energy research and technology, including renewable energy, energy efficiency and advanced and cleaner fossil-fuel technology, and promote investment in energy infrastructure and clean energy technology.
key_indicators: 7.a.1 International financial flows to developing countries in support of clean energy research and development and renewable energy production, including in hybrid systems

targets.description: By 2030, expand infrastructure and upgrade technology for supplying modern and sustainable energy services for all in developing countries, in particular least developed countries, small island developing States, and land-locked developing countries, in accordance with their respective programmes of support.
key_indicators: 7.b.1 Installed renewable energy-generating capacity in developing countries (in watts per capita)

key_statistics: 733 million people worldwide lacked access to electricity in 2021.
2.3 billion people still rely on polluting fuels and technologies for cooking.
Renewable energy accounted for 19.1% of global final energy consumption in 2021.
Global annual rate of improvement in energy efficiency was 2% in 2021, below the 2.6% target.

challenges.challenge: Slow progress in expanding electricity access in Sub-Saharan Africa.
challenges.impact: Millions remain without reliable electricity, hindering education, healthcare, and economic development.

challenges.challenge: High reliance on traditional biomass and polluting cooking fuels.
challenges.impact: Leads to indoor air pollution, health risks, and environmental degradation.

challenges.challenge: Insufficient investment in renewable energy infrastructure in least developed countries.
challenges.impact: Slows the transition to clean energy and limits economic opportunities.

success_stories.initiative: Solar Home Systems program, providing off-grid solar power to rural households.
success_stories.impact: Over 4 million solar home systems installed, benefiting more than 20 million people.

success_stories.initiative: Noor Ouarzazate Solar Complex, one of the world's largest concentrated solar power plants.
success_stories.impact: Supplies electricity to over 2 million people and reduces CO2 emissions by hundreds of thousands of tons annually.

success_stories.initiative: Saubhagya Scheme, aiming for universal household electrification.
success_stories.impact: Over 28 million households electrified since 2017.

priority_actions: Accelerate investment in renewable energy infrastructure, especially in least developed countries.
Expand access to clean cooking solutions and technologies.
Strengthen policy frameworks and incentives for energy efficiency.
Enhance international cooperation and financing for clean energy research and deployment.
Promote decentralized and off-grid energy solutions for remote and rural areas.

interconnections.relationship: Access to clean energy reduces indoor air pollution and improves health outcomes.
Increasing renewable energy use mitigates climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
Affordable energy access is essential for poverty reduction and economic development.
Reliable electricity enables better educational facilities and digital learning.

targets.description: Sustain per capita economic growth in accordance with national circumstances and, in particular, at least 7% gross domestic product growth per annum in the least developed countries.
key_indicators: 8.1.1 Annual growth rate of real GDP per capita

targets.description: Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value added and labor-intensive sectors.
key_indicators: 8.2.1 Annual growth rate of real GDP per employed person

targets.description: Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
key_indicators: 8.3.1 Proportion of informal employment in non‑agriculture employment, by sex

targets.description: Improve progressively, through 2030, global resource efficiency in consumption and production and endeavour to decouple economic growth from environmental degradation, in accordance with the 10-Year Framework of Programmes on Sustainable Consumption and Production, with developed countries taking the lead.
key_indicators: 8.4.1 Material footprint, material footprint per capita, and material footprint per GDP
8.4.2 Domestic material consumption, domestic material consumption per capita, and domestic material consumption per GDP

targets.description: By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.
key_indicators: 8.5.1 Average hourly earnings of female and male employees, by occupation, age and persons with disabilities
8.5.2 Unemployment rate, by sex, age and persons with disabilities

targets.description: By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
key_indicators: 8.6.1 Proportion of youth (aged 15–24 years) not in education, employment or training

targets.description: Take immediate and effective measures to eradicate forced labour, end modern slavery and human trafficking and secure the prohibition and elimination of the worst forms of child labour, including recruitment and use of child soldiers, and by 2025 end child labour in all its forms.
key_indicators: 8.7.1 Proportion and number of children aged 5–17 years engaged in child labour, by sex and age

targets.description: Protect labour rights and promote safe and secure working environments for all workers, including migrant workers, in particular women migrants, and those in precarious employment.
key_indicators: 8.8.1 Fatal and non-fatal occupational injuries per 100,000 workers, by sex and migrant status
8.8.2 Level of national compliance with labour rights (freedom of association and collective bargaining)

targets.description: By 2030, devise and implement policies to promote sustainable tourism that creates jobs and promotes local culture and products.
key_indicators: 8.9.1 Tourism direct GDP as a proportion of total GDP and in growth rate
8.9.2 Number of jobs in tourism industries as a proportion of total jobs and growth rate of jobs, by sex

targets.description: Strengthen the capacity of domestic financial institutions to encourage and expand access to banking, insurance and financial services for all.
key_indicators: 8.10.1 Number of commercial bank branches and ATMs per 100,000 adults
8.10.2 Proportion of adults with an account at a bank or other financial institution or with a mobile-money-service provider

targets.description: Increase Aid for Trade support for developing countries, in particular least developed countries, including through the Enhanced Integrated Framework for Trade-related Technical Assistance to Least Developed Countries.
key_indicators: 8.a.1 Aid for Trade commitments and disbursements

targets.description: By 2020, develop and operationalize a global strategy for youth employment and implement the Global Jobs Pact of the International Labour Organization.
key_indicators: 8.b.1 Existence of a developed and operationalized national strategy for youth employment, as a distinct strategy or as part of a national employment strategy

progress.global_progress_percentage: Approximately 55% of targets are off track
key_statistics: Global real GDP growth per capita was 2.3% in 2022, below the pre-pandemic average.
Global unemployment rate was 5.4% in 2023, down from 6.6% in 2020 but still above pre-pandemic levels in many regions.
In 2022, 23.5% of youth (aged 15–24) were not in employment, education or training.
In 2021, 160 million children were engaged in child labour, with progress stalled since 2016.
The informal employment rate remains above 60% in developing regions.

challenges.challenge: Slow economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic
challenges.impact: Persistently high unemployment rates, especially among youth and women, and increased poverty levels.

challenges.challenge: High prevalence of informal and vulnerable employment
challenges.impact: Lack of social protection, job security, and decent working conditions for a large share of the workforce.

challenges.challenge: Rising child labour and forced labour
challenges.impact: Stalled or reversed progress in eradicating child labour, with millions of children at risk.

challenges.challenge: Limited access to financial services
challenges.impact: Small businesses and vulnerable populations face barriers to entrepreneurship and economic participation.

success_stories.initiative: Expansion of the ready-made garment sector with improved labour rights and safety standards following the Accord on Fire and Building Safety.
success_stories.impact: Over 2 million workers, mostly women, benefited from safer workplaces and higher wages; significant reduction in workplace accidents.

success_stories.initiative: National Youth Employment Strategy focusing on entrepreneurship and skills development.
success_stories.impact: Created over 200,000 new jobs for youth and increased youth participation in the formal economy.

success_stories.initiative: Promotion of digital financial inclusion through mobile banking and fintech solutions.
success_stories.impact: Financial account ownership among adults increased from 31% in 2017 to 69% in 2021.

priority_actions: Accelerate inclusive and sustainable economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic.
Promote formalization of informal employment and extend social protection coverage.
Invest in skills development, especially for youth and women.
Strengthen enforcement of labour rights and workplace safety standards.
Expand access to financial services and support for micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises.
Implement policies to eradicate child labour and forced labour.
Foster innovation and digital transformation to create new decent work opportunities.

interconnections.relationship: Decent work and economic growth are critical for poverty eradication.
Quality education and skills development are essential for productive employment.
Gender equality in the workplace contributes to economic growth.
Industry, innovation, and infrastructure drive productivity and job creation.
Reducing inequalities ensures inclusive economic growth.
Sustainable consumption and production patterns support resource-efficient growth.

targets.description: Develop quality, reliable, sustainable and resilient infrastructure, including regional and transborder infrastructure, to support economic development and human well-being, with a focus on affordable and equitable access for all.
key_indicators: 9.1.1: Proportion of the rural population who live within 2 km of an all-season road
9.1.2: Passenger and freight volumes, by mode of transport

targets.description: Promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and, by 2030, significantly raise industry’s share of employment and gross domestic product, in line with national circumstances, and double its share in least developed countries.
key_indicators: 9.2.1: Manufacturing value added as a proportion of GDP and per capita
9.2.2: Manufacturing employment as a proportion of total employment

targets.description: Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets.
key_indicators: 9.3.1: Proportion of small-scale industries in total industry value added
9.3.2: Proportion of small-scale industries with a loan or line of credit

targets.description: By 2030, upgrade infrastructure and retrofit industries to make them sustainable, with increased resource-use efficiency and greater adoption of clean and environmentally sound technologies and industrial processes, with all countries taking action in accordance with their respective capabilities.
key_indicators: 9.4.1: CO2 emission per unit of value added

targets.description: Enhance scientific research, upgrade the technological capabilities of industrial sectors in all countries, in particular developing countries, including, by 2030, encouraging innovation and substantially increasing the number of research and development workers per 1 million people and public and private research and development spending.
key_indicators: 9.5.1: Research and development expenditure as a proportion of GDP
9.5.2: Researchers (in full-time equivalent) per million inhabitants

targets.description: Facilitate sustainable and resilient infrastructure development in developing countries through enhanced financial, technological and technical support to African countries, least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States.
key_indicators: 9.a.1: Total official international support (official development assistance plus other official flows) to infrastructure

targets.description: Support domestic technology development, research and innovation in developing countries, including by ensuring a conducive policy environment for, inter alia, industrial diversification and value addition to commodities.
key_indicators: 9.b.1: Proportion of medium and high-tech industry value added in total value added

targets.description: Significantly increase access to information and communications technology and strive to provide universal and affordable access to the Internet in least developed countries by 2020.
key_indicators: 9.c.1: Proportion of population covered by a mobile network, by technology

progress.global_progress_percentage: Approximately 60% of targets show moderate progress
key_statistics: Global manufacturing value added per capita increased from $1,560 in 2015 to $1,740 in 2022 (constant 2015 USD).
In 2022, 95% of the world population was covered by a mobile broadband network, but only 36% in least developed countries had internet access.
CO2 emissions per unit of manufacturing value added decreased by 25% globally between 2010 and 2021.

challenges.challenge: Limited access to reliable infrastructure in rural and remote areas.
challenges.impact: Hinders economic opportunities, access to markets, and essential services for millions of people.

challenges.challenge: Slow progress in industrialization and value addition in least developed countries.
challenges.impact: Limits job creation, economic diversification, and poverty reduction.

challenges.challenge: Digital divide and lack of affordable internet access.
challenges.impact: Exacerbates inequalities in education, business, and access to information.

success_stories.initiative: Development of high-tech industrial parks and investment in digital infrastructure.
success_stories.impact: Manufacturing value added as a share of GDP increased from 16% in 2010 to 25% in 2022; over 70% of the population now has internet access.

success_stories.initiative: Nationwide rollout of 4G LTE network to improve digital connectivity.
success_stories.impact: Internet penetration increased from 7% in 2012 to over 60% in 2022, boosting digital entrepreneurship and access to services.

success_stories.initiative: Promotion of Industry 4.0 and green manufacturing technologies.
success_stories.impact: CO2 emissions per unit of manufacturing value added decreased by 30% between 2010 and 2021.

priority_actions: Increase investment in resilient and sustainable infrastructure, especially in least developed and landlocked countries.
Promote inclusive industrialization and support small-scale enterprises with access to finance and markets.
Accelerate digital transformation and close the digital divide through affordable internet access.
Foster innovation and research by increasing R&D spending and supporting technology transfer.
Promote adoption of clean and environmentally sound technologies in industry.

interconnections.relationship: Industrialization and infrastructure development are critical for poverty reduction through job creation and economic growth.
Sustainable infrastructure supports access to affordable and clean energy.
Industrialization drives economic growth and decent work opportunities.
Urban infrastructure development is essential for sustainable cities and communities.
Upgrading industries and infrastructure to be more sustainable helps mitigate climate change.

targets.description: By 2030, progressively achieve and sustain income growth of the bottom 40% of the population at a rate higher than the national average.
key_indicators: 10.1.1: Growth rates of household expenditure or income per capita among the bottom 40% and the total population

targets.description: By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.
key_indicators: 10.2.1: Proportion of people living below 50% of median income, by age, sex and persons with disabilities

targets.description: Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action.
key_indicators: 10.3.1: Proportion of population reporting having personally felt discriminated against or harassed

targets.description: Adopt policies, especially fiscal, wage and social protection policies, and progressively achieve greater equality.
key_indicators: 10.4.1: Labour share of GDP, comprising wages and social protection transfers

targets.description: Improve the regulation and monitoring of global financial markets and institutions and strengthen the implementation of such regulations.
key_indicators: 10.5.1: Financial Soundness Indicators

targets.description: Ensure enhanced representation and voice for developing countries in decision-making in global international economic and financial institutions.
key_indicators: 10.6.1: Proportion of members and voting rights of developing countries in international organizations

targets.description: Facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people, including through implementation of planned and well-managed migration policies.
key_indicators: 10.7.1: Recruitment cost borne by employee as a proportion of yearly income earned in destination country
10.7.2: Number of countries with migration policies that facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people

targets.description: Implement the principle of special and differential treatment for developing countries, in particular least developed countries, in accordance with World Trade Organization agreements.
key_indicators: 10.a.1: Proportion of tariff lines applied to imports from least developed countries and developing countries with zero-tariff

targets.description: Encourage official development assistance and financial flows, including foreign direct investment, to States where the need is greatest.
key_indicators: 10.b.1: Total resource flows for development, by recipient and donor countries and type of flow

targets.description: By 2030, reduce to less than 3% the transaction costs of migrant remittances and eliminate remittance corridors with costs higher than 5%.
key_indicators: 10.c.1: Remittance costs as a proportion of the amount remitted

progress.global_progress_percentage: Less than 30% of targets on track
key_statistics: The income of the bottom 40% of the population grew faster than the national average in only 38 of 91 countries with data (2012–2021).
The global Gini index remains high, with income inequality persisting within and between countries.
Remittance costs averaged 6.2% in 2023, above the SDG target of 3%.
Discrimination based on age, gender, ethnicity, and disability remains widespread.

challenges.challenge: Persistent income and wealth inequality within and between countries.
challenges.impact: Limits social mobility, increases poverty, and undermines social cohesion.

challenges.challenge: High cost of remittances for migrant workers.
challenges.impact: Reduces the amount of money families in developing countries receive, affecting their livelihoods.

challenges.challenge: Discrimination and exclusion based on gender, age, disability, and ethnicity.
challenges.impact: Leads to unequal access to education, employment, and political participation.

success_stories.initiative: Targeted poverty reduction and social protection programs, including cash transfers and inclusive education policies.
success_stories.impact: Poverty rate reduced from 58% in 1993 to below 6% in 2022, with significant narrowing of rural-urban and ethnic minority gaps.

success_stories.initiative: Comprehensive anti-discrimination legislation and strong social welfare policies.
success_stories.impact: High levels of social inclusion and one of the lowest income inequality rates in the OECD.

success_stories.initiative: National Strategy for Immigration and Asylum, providing migrants with access to health, education, and legal protection.
success_stories.impact: Regularized status for over 50,000 migrants and improved access to essential services.

priority_actions: Strengthen social protection systems and expand coverage to vulnerable groups.
Promote inclusive economic growth and decent work opportunities.
Reduce remittance costs and improve financial inclusion for migrants.
Enforce anti-discrimination laws and promote equal access to education and healthcare.
Enhance representation of developing countries in global decision-making institutions.
Support fiscal and wage policies that reduce income and wealth disparities.

interconnections.relationship: Reducing inequalities is essential for ending poverty in all its forms.
Gender equality is a key component of reducing inequalities within and among countries.
Inclusive economic growth and decent work help reduce income disparities.
Peaceful and inclusive societies support the reduction of discrimination and inequalities.

targets.description: By 2030, ensure access for all to adequate, safe and affordable housing and basic services and upgrade slums.
key_indicators: 11.1.1: Proportion of urban population living in slums, informal settlements or inadequate housing

targets.description: By 2030, provide access to safe, affordable, accessible and sustainable transport systems for all, improving road safety, notably by expanding public transport, with special attention to the needs of those in vulnerable situations, women, children, persons with disabilities and older persons.
key_indicators: 11.2.1: Proportion of population that has convenient access to public transport, by sex, age and persons with disabilities

targets.description: By 2030, enhance inclusive and sustainable urbanization and capacity for participatory, integrated and sustainable human settlement planning and management in all countries.
key_indicators: 11.3.1: Ratio of land consumption rate to population growth rate
11.3.2: Proportion of cities with a direct participation structure of civil society in urban planning and management

targets.description: Strengthen efforts to protect and safeguard the world’s cultural and natural heritage.
key_indicators: 11.4.1: Total expenditure (public and private) per capita spent on the preservation, protection and conservation of all cultural and natural heritage

targets.description: By 2030, significantly reduce the number of deaths and the number of people affected and substantially decrease the direct economic losses relative to global gross domestic product caused by disasters, including water-related disasters, with a focus on protecting the poor and people in vulnerable situations.
key_indicators: 11.5.1: Number of deaths, missing persons and directly affected persons attributed to disasters per 100,000 population
11.5.2: Direct economic loss in relation to global GDP, damage to critical infrastructure and number of disruptions to basic services, attributed to disasters

targets.description: By 2030, reduce the adverse per capita environmental impact of cities, including by paying special attention to air quality and municipal and other waste management.
key_indicators: 11.6.1: Proportion of urban solid waste regularly collected and with adequate final discharge out of total urban solid waste generated
11.6.2: Annual mean levels of fine particulate matter (e.g. PM2.5 and PM10) in cities

targets.description: By 2030, provide universal access to safe, inclusive and accessible, green and public spaces, in particular for women and children, older persons and persons with disabilities.
key_indicators: 11.7.1: Average share of the built-up area of cities that is open space for public use for all, by sex, age and persons with disabilities
11.7.2: Proportion of persons victim of physical or sexual harassment, by sex, age, disability status and place of occurrence

targets.description: Support positive economic, social and environmental links between urban, peri-urban and rural areas by strengthening national and regional development planning.
key_indicators: 11.a.1: Number of countries that have national urban policies or regional development plans that respond to population dynamics

targets.description: By 2020, substantially increase the number of cities and human settlements adopting and implementing integrated policies and plans towards inclusion, resource efficiency, mitigation and adaptation to climate change, resilience to disasters, and develop and implement, in line with the Sendai Framework, holistic disaster risk management at all levels.
key_indicators: 11.b.1: Number of countries with national and local disaster risk reduction strategies
11.b.2: Proportion of local governments that adopt and implement local disaster risk reduction strategies

targets.description: Support least developed countries, including through financial and technical assistance, in building sustainable and resilient buildings utilizing local materials.
key_indicators: 11.c.1: Proportion of financial support to the least developed countries that is allocated to the construction and retrofitting of sustainable, resilient and resource-efficient buildings utilizing local materials

progress.global_progress_percentage: Less than 30% of targets on track
key_statistics: Over 1 billion people live in slums or informal settlements as of 2022.
Only 52% of the world’s urban population has convenient access to public transport (2022).
Air pollution levels in most cities exceed WHO guidelines, with 99% of the global population breathing air that exceeds recommended limits.
Urban areas account for over 70% of global CO2 emissions.
Disaster-related economic losses in urban areas reached $253 billion in 2022.

challenges.challenge: Rapid urbanization leading to the expansion of slums and informal settlements.
challenges.impact: Increases in inadequate housing, lack of basic services, and heightened vulnerability to health and environmental hazards.

challenges.challenge: Insufficient investment in sustainable public transport systems.
challenges.impact: Limited mobility for vulnerable populations, increased traffic congestion, and higher greenhouse gas emissions.

challenges.challenge: High levels of urban air pollution and poor waste management.
challenges.impact: Adverse health outcomes, environmental degradation, and reduced quality of life.

challenges.challenge: Inadequate disaster risk reduction and resilience planning.
challenges.impact: Increased loss of life and economic damage from natural disasters, particularly among the urban poor.

success_stories.initiative: Medellín's urban transformation through integrated public transport, social housing, and green spaces.
success_stories.impact: Reduction in homicide rates by over 80%, improved mobility for 1.5 million residents, and increased access to public spaces.

success_stories.initiative: Smart Cities Mission focusing on sustainable urban infrastructure, digital services, and green mobility.
success_stories.impact: Over 100 cities implementing projects benefiting more than 100 million people with improved sanitation, transport, and e-governance.

success_stories.initiative: Copenhagen's commitment to carbon-neutral urban planning and cycling infrastructure.
success_stories.impact: Over 62% of city residents commute by bike, contributing to a 42% reduction in CO2 emissions since 2005.

priority_actions: Increase investment in affordable and resilient housing, especially in informal settlements.
Expand and modernize sustainable public transport systems.
Strengthen urban planning to promote green spaces and reduce urban sprawl.
Implement stricter air quality and waste management regulations.
Enhance disaster risk reduction strategies and urban resilience.
Promote inclusive participation in urban governance and planning.
Support least developed countries with financial and technical assistance for sustainable urban infrastructure.

interconnections.relationship: Improved urban air quality and access to green spaces contribute to better health and well-being.
Urban water and sanitation infrastructure is essential for clean water and sanitation.
Energy-efficient buildings and sustainable transport reduce energy consumption.
Urban resilience and low-carbon development are critical for climate action.
Urban expansion impacts terrestrial ecosystems and biodiversity.

targets.description: Implement the 10-Year Framework of Programmes on sustainable consumption and production, all countries taking action, with developed countries taking the lead.
key_indicators: 12.1.1 Number of countries with SCP national action plans or SCP mainstreamed as a priority or a target into national policies

targets.description: By 2030, achieve the sustainable management and efficient use of natural resources.
key_indicators: 12.2.1 Material footprint, material footprint per capita, and material footprint per GDP
12.2.2 Domestic material consumption, domestic material consumption per capita, and domestic material consumption per GDP

targets.description: By 2030, halve per capita global food waste at the retail and consumer levels and reduce food losses along production and supply chains, including post-harvest losses.
key_indicators: 12.3.1 Global food loss index

targets.description: By 2020, achieve the environmentally sound management of chemicals and all wastes throughout their life cycle, in accordance with agreed international frameworks, and significantly reduce their release to air, water and soil.
key_indicators: 12.4.1 Number of parties to international multilateral environmental agreements on hazardous waste, chemicals and other wastes
12.4.2 Hazardous waste generated per capita and proportion of hazardous waste treated

targets.description: By 2030, substantially reduce waste generation through prevention, reduction, recycling and reuse.
key_indicators: 12.5.1 National recycling rate, tons of material recycled

targets.description: Encourage companies, especially large and transnational companies, to adopt sustainable practices and to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycle.
key_indicators: 12.6.1 Number of companies publishing sustainability reports

targets.description: Promote public procurement practices that are sustainable, in accordance with national policies and priorities.
key_indicators: 12.7.1 Number of countries implementing sustainable public procurement policies and action plans

targets.description: By 2030, ensure that people everywhere have the relevant information and awareness for sustainable development and lifestyles in harmony with nature.
key_indicators: 12.8.1 Extent to which (i) global citizenship education and (ii) education for sustainable development are mainstreamed in national education policies, curricula, teacher education and student assessment

targets.description: Support developing countries to strengthen their scientific and technological capacity to move towards more sustainable patterns of consumption and production.
key_indicators: 12.a.1 Amount of support to developing countries on research and development for sustainable consumption and production and environmentally sound technologies

targets.description: Develop and implement tools to monitor sustainable development impacts for sustainable tourism that creates jobs and promotes local culture and products.
key_indicators: 12.b.1 Number of sustainable tourism strategies or policies and implemented action plans with agreed monitoring and evaluation tools

targets.description: Rationalize inefficient fossil-fuel subsidies that encourage wasteful consumption by removing market distortions.
key_indicators: 12.c.1 Amount of fossil-fuel subsidies per unit of GDP (production and consumption)

progress.global_progress_percentage: Less than 20% of targets on track
key_statistics: Global material footprint reached 95.9 billion metric tons in 2019, up from 73.2 billion in 2010.
Food loss and waste accounts for about 8-10% of global greenhouse gas emissions.
Only 13.5% of e-waste was recycled globally in 2022.
Fossil fuel subsidies nearly doubled in 2022 to $1.3 trillion.

challenges.challenge: Rising material consumption and inefficient resource use.
challenges.impact: Increased environmental degradation, higher greenhouse gas emissions, and depletion of natural resources.

challenges.challenge: High levels of food loss and waste across supply chains.
challenges.impact: Loss of resources, increased food insecurity, and significant greenhouse gas emissions.

challenges.challenge: Persistent fossil fuel subsidies.
challenges.impact: Encourages wasteful consumption, hinders transition to renewable energy, and increases emissions.

challenges.challenge: Limited adoption of sustainable business practices and reporting.
challenges.impact: Slow progress towards transparency and accountability in supply chains.

success_stories.initiative: Implementation of a national food waste reduction program, including public awareness campaigns and incentives for retailers and consumers.
success_stories.impact: Reduced food waste by 15% between 2015 and 2022.

success_stories.initiative: Ban on single-use plastics and promotion of sustainable alternatives.
success_stories.impact: Significant reduction in plastic waste and improved urban cleanliness.

success_stories.initiative: Home Appliance Recycling Law requiring manufacturers to recycle appliances and consumers to pay recycling fees.
success_stories.impact: Recycling rates for appliances exceeded 90% by 2021.

priority_actions: Accelerate implementation of sustainable consumption and production policies.
Scale up food loss and waste reduction initiatives.
Phase out inefficient fossil fuel subsidies.
Promote circular economy approaches and resource efficiency.
Enhance sustainability reporting and responsible business practices.
Increase investment in sustainable infrastructure and technologies.
Strengthen education and awareness on sustainable lifestyles.

interconnections.relationship: Reducing food loss and waste supports Zero Hunger by improving food availability and resource efficiency.
Phasing out fossil fuel subsidies and promoting energy efficiency supports Affordable and Clean Energy.
Responsible consumption and production reduces greenhouse gas emissions, supporting Climate Action.
Reducing waste and pollution protects Life Below Water.
Sustainable resource use helps conserve terrestrial ecosystems and biodiversity.

targets.description: Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
key_indicators: 13.1.1: Number of deaths, missing persons and directly affected persons attributed to disasters per 100,000 population
13.1.2: Number of countries with national and local disaster risk reduction strategies

targets.description: Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.
key_indicators: 13.2.1: Number of countries with nationally determined contributions, long-term strategies, national adaptation plans, and adaptation communications
13.2.2: Total greenhouse gas emissions per year

targets.description: Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
key_indicators: 13.3.1: Number of countries that have integrated mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning into curricula
13.3.2: Number of countries with climate change education and awareness programmes

targets.description: Implement the commitment undertaken by developed-country parties to the UNFCCC to a goal of mobilizing jointly $100 billion annually by 2020 to address the needs of developing countries.
key_indicators: 13.a.1: Amounts provided and mobilized in USD per year in relation to the continued existing collective mobilization goal of the $100 billion commitment

targets.description: Promote mechanisms for raising capacity for effective climate change-related planning and management in least developed countries and small island developing States.
key_indicators: 13.b.1: Number of least developed countries and small island developing States with climate change strategies and plans

progress.global_progress_percentage: Less than 20% of required emissions reductions achieved
key_statistics: Global greenhouse gas emissions reached a record high of 57.4 GtCO2e in 2022.
The world is on track for a temperature rise of 2.5°C to 2.9°C by 2100 under current policies.
Only 38% of countries have comprehensive disaster risk reduction strategies in place.
Climate finance flows to developing countries reached $83.3 billion in 2020, still below the $100 billion target.

challenges.challenge: Insufficient reduction in greenhouse gas emissions
challenges.impact: Continued rise in global temperatures, increased frequency and severity of extreme weather events.

challenges.challenge: Inadequate climate finance for developing countries
challenges.impact: Limited capacity for adaptation and mitigation, increased vulnerability to climate impacts.

challenges.challenge: Lack of integration of climate action into national policies
challenges.impact: Slow progress on adaptation and mitigation, missed opportunities for sustainable development.

success_stories.initiative: Transition to renewable energy with over 50% of electricity generated from wind and solar power.
success_stories.impact: Significant reduction in national greenhouse gas emissions; on track to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050.

success_stories.initiative: National decarbonization plan and investment in hydropower and reforestation.
success_stories.impact: Over 98% of electricity from renewable sources; increased forest cover to over 50% of land area.

success_stories.initiative: Community-based early warning systems for cyclones and floods.
success_stories.impact: Dramatic reduction in cyclone-related deaths and improved disaster preparedness.

priority_actions: Accelerate the transition to renewable energy sources globally
Scale up climate finance and fulfill the $100 billion annual commitment
Strengthen national adaptation plans and disaster risk reduction strategies
Integrate climate action into all sectors and policies
Enhance climate education and public awareness
Support vulnerable countries and communities in building resilience

interconnections.relationship: Climate change impacts agricultural productivity and food security.
Climate change affects water availability and increases the risk of droughts and floods.
Transitioning to clean energy is essential for reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
Urban areas must adapt to climate risks and reduce emissions.
Climate change leads to ocean warming, acidification, and sea level rise.
Climate change threatens terrestrial ecosystems and biodiversity.

targets.description: By 2025, prevent and significantly reduce marine pollution of all kinds, in particular from land-based activities, including marine debris and nutrient pollution.
key_indicators: 14.1.1: Index of coastal eutrophication and floating plastic debris density
